subject: Fix #60 by adding encoding/decoding rules
commitMessage:
Fix #60 by adding encoding/decoding rules

This commit attempts to make encoding more compatible with things within
openbmc that don't encode paths per the systemd method.  It does this by
forcing the first character of every path segment to be encoded, so /abc
would be encoded as /_61bc.  This is then used as a mechanism to
determine if the path needs to be decoded per systemds rules.

The decode mechanisms are also modified to check whether the first
element is encoded before decoding the portion.

Looking for input on whether this is an OK path.  The hope would be that
we slowly transition the system over to using the encoding mechanisms
that can handle all ascii characters, and can round trip through
encode/decode without loss.  The hope is that this patch can be reversed
at some point in the future.

As an aside, I tried reverting some of the patches, but they're somewhat
ungainly to revert at this point, and would require reverting some
bmcweb patches, which, if this patch is determined to be bad, I'm happy
to do, but I'm hoping this will get us something in the interim

Tested:
unit tests added and updated to cover some of the cases.  Unit tests
pass.

Change-Id: Ie9c8cd0627b8b086e8b0bb2287f28dd86eb98ee9
Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <edtanous@google.com>

Signed-off ?
Done
It would be easier / faster to rfind('/') directly here. The beginning of the filename would be the index or 0 if not found and you wouldn't need to construct the parent path only to discard it.
We do use parent on line 169, so we'd need to generate it for that path either way, but I think you're right, this could be more efficient if we did the rfind first.

I would just use sd_bus_encode_path_many / sd_bus_decode_path_many with "%" as the format string since it doesn't require the parent path at all. Would have been nice if they had a simple  `sd_bus_{encode,decode}` function.

sd_bus_path_decode_many would still require the parent path, as we have to pass in the "prefix" as part of the decode so we get only the arg we want out.

Or I'm really missing something on that method.

This isn't fixed in the latest patchset, I need to look a little deeper at how to simplify this.
You just need to use sd_bus_encode_path_many(&out, "%", to_escape) and sd_bus_decode_path_many(to_unescape, "", &out)
sd_bus_decode_path_many(to_unescape, "", &out) will decode the slashes into escape characters, right?  Isn't that the whole reason why you need the parent as the input?
You don't need to know what the parent string is though, you just need a substring reference that contains the filename.
I gotcha now.  Let me try to code that up.
Done in the latest patchset.
Too bad gcc doesn't support array length deduction with partial specialization until 11.

but there's something so satisfying about seeing 16 there 😋

Time to switch to rust.

> Time to switch to rust.

I'm +1 on that, but I think Rust happens to suffer from pretty much the exact same problem unfortunately: https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2545

I'll leave this one up to the maintainer if he wants me to change it.  std::array is more "modern" because you can do range checks in a much more consistent way with .size(), but in this case, because we don't do any range checks (because they're intrinsically safe with our shifts).  I don't have a strong preference here.

At the very least, leaving this as a c++ array would let us enable the:
https://clang.llvm.org/extra/clang-tidy/checks/modernize-avoid-c-arrays.html
clang-tidy check across this whole project in the future.
firstChar could theoretically be negative, right?
Fixed on latest patchset.
This changes the previous behavior, I am not sure if there is existing code that depends on this API, if yes, how do we make sure they are not affected?

This is intentionally changing old behavior because of #60;  I believe I wrote most (all?) of the current usages of operator/ that exist at this point, and for at least the things I've done sofar, this is better behavior.

In a perfect world, we wouldn't need any of this, but we need to transition some APIs around, and this was the best of the mediocre options.

This is missing a test case for
`sdbusplus::message::object_path("/abc") / "bios_active"`
->
`sdbusplus::message::object_path("/abc/bios_active")`
Ack
Done
Will you expand upon "proper encoding mechanisms"?
Updated what I think "proper" would mean in terms of requirements, not in terms of implementation.
This should be sdbusplus::message::object_path("/abc/ab_cd") so that path construction is consistent with appenidng. Ex sdbusplus::message::object_path("/") / "xyz" / "openbmc_project"
nit: This check is redundant as substr(str.size()) will do this implicitly

Then I'd have to catch that exception and return this same thing?   That seems like it would be more code.  Some of this is stemming from me trying to handle all corner cases of bad paths, like empty string, and return them in a sane way.  This was previous std::optional, but patrick wanted it to be more like std::filesystem, so I tried to make the behavior match.
There is no exception, you can just delete the code. substr(str.size()) is legal and returns "".
I tried to do it without the check in patchset 8, but valgrind didn't like it.  There might still be a bug in my code, but I'm not seeing it.

`std::string_view filename = str.substr(firstIndex);`

creates a temporary std::string and that's what ubasan doesn't like.

`auto filename = std::string_view(str).substr(firstIndex);`

will reference str directly.

> `std::string_view filename = str.substr(firstIndex);`
> 
> creates a temporary std::string and that's what ubasan doesn't like.
> 

That seems so obvious now.....  DOH.

> `auto filename = std::string_view(str).substr(firstIndex);`
> 
> will reference str directly.

Obvious? How is that obvious?
Obfuscated I can accept.
nit: We should prefer a string view here to avoid the intermediate string copy.

I'm wary to do that because we need a null terminated string to pass to sd_bus_path_decode_many later, also on line 167, we might have to construct a string from said string_view anyway.

Technically you can't rely on std::string_view.data() being null terminated, although I suspect we should be able to in this case because all std::strings are null terminated these days, and while string_view doesn't guarantee that, std::string does, so, only kind of undefined behavior?

If you think that's really the right thing to do, I can make that change here, but I suspect that's going to be worse in terms of peoples mental model and style for std::string_view.data().

Right, std::string_view wouldn't work nicely here. I would just use `auto filename = str.c_str() + firstIndex` then. It would still work the same as substr, even if you remove the size() check above. And you could return it / use it in sd_bus_path*
I did this with string_view;  That seemed better than going to raw pointers.

For zstrings, I would just keep the `char*` type. You wouldn't need to check `.empty()` prior to accessing `filename[0]` since you can always depend on the nul terminator existing at the end of the string. You also wouldn't need to make two independent substrings with a string_view and then a `filename.c_str() + firstIndex` later.
Ack
Probably worth fixing this separately / having a test for it?

We can fix it in another patch.  This was only really required for when I used parent_path above to handle one of the non-conforming dbus path test cases, but now that we're not using this, correct, I suspect this doesn't need to be this way.

Will fix in next patch.
typo

no, it isn't

nit: This can reference `filename` now
Done
Why wouldn't you return str in this case?
Because we previously defined empty string as the "error" return, and if this fires, it means that the dbus path isn't valid.

Oh... dbus paths must start with "/".

Could use a comment then if I forgot it. 😊
Done
I think you could use a few comments from here to the end.  At least what you're attempting to do at a high-level.
Done;  I also moved this array lower in the file so that the comment makes more sense in context.
This is not obvious what you're catching with this.
I think this check got invalidated when we went to pointers.  In theory it was checking whether the last character was a /, but now I don't think it's needed.  Removed.

I'd prefer you create a char[4] and do a single insert.

A small optimization would be to flip the first character to a _ and insert just the hex part.

I did the small optimization path, and did an insert of char[2] after replacing the first character with _

The array constructor looks a little messy, but breaking it up seemed worse (although I'm on the fence there).
